multiple_choice_question.text: What does the acronym "CR" stand for in the table?
choices: Characteristic Root
Capped Relative
Computed Relative
Computed Root

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the meaning of the values in the "FP" column?
choices: First position of a correct digit in the computed characteristic polynomial coefficient
First position of an incorrect digit in the computed characteristic polynomial coefficient
Final precision of the computed characteristic polynomial coefficient
Floating-point representation of the computed characteristic polynomial coefficient

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from the results presented in Figure 1?
choices: The "CR" method consistently outperforms both the "Optimal" and "FP" methods in terms of accuracy.
The "FP" method suffers from significant loss of precision, especially for higher-degree coefficients.
The "Optimal" method demonstrates a controlled and predictable loss of precision compared to the other methods.
There is no significant difference in accuracy between the three methods presented.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the variable *N* in Formula (6) represent?
choices: The degree of the characteristic polynomial
The optimal precision on the k-th coefficient of the characteristic polynomial
The valuation of the determinant of the matrix M
The number of rows/columns in the matrix M

multiple_choice_question.text: What simplification does Formula (8) offer compared to Formula (7)?
choices: It applies to matrices with entries in any field, not just OK.
It calculates the optimal precision on all eigenvalues simultaneously.
It eliminates the need to compute the comatrix of (X-M).
It provides a more computationally efficient calculation when M is given at flat precision.
